title: Thursday Morning Business Brief
text:
October 8, 2015, 6:25 AM HONG KONG - 
Pent-up investor demand fueled a jump in Shanghai stocks after Chinese markets reopened today following an extended holiday but other world bourses were lackluster. European shares are uneven in early trading, with markets in France and Germany slightly up, but slightly down in Britain. U.S. investors are hoping for gains today following yesterday's performance. The Dow rose 122 points to 16,912. The S&P 500 added 16 points to 1.996. And the Nasdaq rose 43 points to 4,791. WASHINGTON (AP) - The Labor Department releases weekly jobless claims at 8:30 a.m. Eastern Time. Freddie Mac, the mortgage company, releases weekly mortgage rates at 10 a.m. And the Federal Reserve releases minutes from its September interest-rate meeting. WASHINGTON (AP) - Volkswagen's top U.S. executive is expected to face tough questions on Capitol Hill today as the emissions-rigging scandal enveloping the world's largest automaker appears to be deepening. VW's plans to withdraw applications for U.S. emissions certifications for its 2016 model Jettas, Golfs, Passats and Beetles with diesel engines. That raises questions about whether those models also have been fitted with a so-called "defeat device" that allowed Volkswagen to cheat on government emissions tests. DETROIT (AP) - Fiat Chrysler has avoided an expensive strike at its U.S. plants after reaching a tentative labor agreement with the United Auto Workers union. The UAW announced the agreement just before midnight last night. Local union leaders will vote on the proposed deal Friday at a meeting in Detroit. The company says it won't get into the specifics of the tentative agreement, but last week the union rejected an offer that included pay raises, the potential for increased profit sharing and a $3,000 signing bonus. NEW YORK (AP) - Amazon has launched a site for handcrafted goods called Amazon Handmade. Amazon is hoping to capitalize on shoppers' appetite for homemade goods ahead of the holiday season. The site, started today, offers everything from $30 walnut cufflinks from Australia to $325 handmade quilts from Wisconsin. Initially, there are about 5,000 sellers from 50 states and 60 countries offering some 80,000 items. Amazon takes a 12 percent fee from overall sales. Â© 2015 Associated Press. All rights reserved.
